abstract.p: Carlos Franco wins $3.5 million Compaq Classic golf tournament in New Orleans (S)

block.p: Carlos Franco, the defending champion, survived a bogey on the first playoff hole and then made a 3-foot putt for par on the second to win the $3.5 million Compaq Classic yesterday in New Orleans.
The 18th hole was the undoing of Blaine McCallister in both regulation and the playoff.
Carlos Franco, the defending champion, survived a bogey on the first playoff hole and then made a 3-foot putt for par on the second to win the $3.5 million Compaq Classic yesterday in New Orleans.
The 18th hole was the undoing of Blaine McCallister in both regulation and the playoff.

McCallister, who last won a PGA tournament in 1993, had a one-stroke lead over Franco after 17 holes. His second shot on the 72nd hole went into the front bunker, and he missed a 12-foot putt for par. Franco saved par by making a 5-footer, leaving both with closing four-under-par 68's and 18-under 270 totals at the 7,116-yard English Turn Golf and Country Club course.
The playoff started on No. 18, and Franco hit into a fairway bunker off the tee. His third shot went to the fringe of the green and he went about 5 feet past the hole and made a bogey 5.
McCallister was on in two and had about a 30-footer for birdie, but he missed that and a 6-footer for par.
On the second playoff hole, the par-4 16th, McCallister hit into a bunker off the tee and then into a greenside trap, which he could not get out of. His fourth shot went through the green.
Franco's second shot also went into a greenside trap, but he hit within 3 feet and made the putt for the $612,000 first prize.
Last year's victory in New Orleans was the first PGA Tour victory for Franco, a native of Paraguay. His eight rounds in this tournament have all been in the 60's.

DAVIES HANGS ON: Laura Davies of England shot a two-over-par 72 but held on for a two-stroke victory over Dottie Pepper in the Philips Invitational in Austin, Tex. Davies finished at five-under 275 to claim her second title of the year and the 60th of her international career. She needs just 3 more points in the L.P.G.A.'s scoring system for automatic qualification to the Hall of Fame.

Pepper started the day seven strokes off the lead but closed with three birdies over the final six holes for a 67. She watched from the clubhouse for an hour as her score kept moving her up the leader board.
Davies started the final round with a three-stroke lead over Susie Redman and Tammie Green before struggles with her putter let the field stay close on the final day.

FLEISHER WINS AGAIN: Bruce Fleisher won his third Senior PGA Tour event of the season, making a birdie on the third playoff hole to beat Hubert Green and retain his title in the Home Depot Invitational at Charlotte, N.C.
Fleisher, who closed with a 68, is the only player on the 50-and-over circuit to win more than once this year. He earned $195,000 with the victory to move within $17,000 of $1 million.
Fleisher and Green each matched the tournament record with 13-under-par 203 finishes. Bob Murphy, Lee Trevino and Don Bies also share that 54-hole mark.

Both players birdied and parred the first two playoff holes before Fleisher hit a 90-yard approach shot to 3 feet on the par-5 18th hole. Green missed his 12-foot birdie putt just left and Fleisher -- after backing away once -- sank his short one for the victory.
